reviewText:
The Knobbly Crook is a free to play indie adventure game in the vein of 'Monkey Island'. It will apparently be several episodes long, all of them 100% free

Pros:
has a good sense of humor
a unique, pleasing art style
good music, fits the atmosphere
totally free

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YCtyOvgNzK8

Cons:
notable lack of options
the sound effects of the characters speaking is a really unpleasant robotic screeching
it may just be that i'm not great at this type of game, but it's REALLY difficult to tell what to do, right from the start


It's totally free so there's no reason to not check it out. Especially if you're a fan of the genre.

reviewText: Short (it's the first in an episodic adventure series) but extremely high quality game, The Knobbly Crook Chapter I is set in an extremely cool fantasy world. You get a strong sense that there's a massive backstory and a big world yet to explore, even though the game itself takes place in a single location. The puzzles are pretty straightforward, and I only had a little difficulty in one spot. The dialog is pretty funny in general, and the weird voices and characters are great. Anyone who enjoys point-and-click adventures will love this one. And since it's FREE, it's easy to recommend. There's abolutely no reason not to check it out. Do so, and you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: Cool music, funny conversations. Puzzles aren't that hard, but I needed some hints (walkthrough video). Took me 2 hours to complete in total. Looking forward to chapter two!

reviewText:
Wether you like the genre or not, THIS is one game that is absolutely worth experiencing for 3 simple reasons.
Pro's:
-It's free. It's so good it should have a price to it, but it's free. Why.
-Dark humor mixed with childish humor. The entire game is a spin around the idea that we need to have a ''second name'' in the world. See, back in the day before WW1 or 2, that used to be a thing. John the Smith, John the Shepperd and John the Pervert were three different men. Albeit John might have just been a blacksmith who liked butt♥♥♥♥ing sheep while wearing plate mail armor...the reason you needed a second name was to identify WHO you are and what you do.
-The graphical style seems rather terrifying at first look, but once you get past the first screen that you are given, you start seeing things from a different angle.
Con's:
-If you get stuck somewhere you have to resort to the good old rub everything to everything until something happens.
-If you are still stuck afterwards, think about something illogical and silly yet logical in the same time. The only time I got stuck was when... yeah won't spoil what's the answer but I NEED to leave a hint here because the answer was alien as all hell. TUBA. MUSIC. GOT IT? TOUCH IT.
-It's not done yet. I want more, what can I say?

I went in with doubts and low expectations and I came out with a grin as wide as my ears, wearing a suit made out of metal that is indestructible unless hit by a rock.

reviewText:
Lovingly crafted, freakishly surreal, beautifully drawn and wittily written, the Knobbly Crook's brief first chapter promises to lift point-and-click adventures to new heights while at the same time holding on to the classic item-based puzzles of the genre. And all for free.

Despite its surreal approach and the implied violence of its plot, this is the kind of the game that leaves me with the kind of warm feeling I get when I watch a Wallace and Gromit animation. It even has cute (although potentially lethal) tribble-like creatures by the boatload.

When I say surreal, I'm not just saying there are some funny colours in a few places and some “kooky” characters who say some slightly silly things.

I'm saying this is a full-on sick, warped, renaissance-era fantasy version of our world where exploring means diving into the acid-filled bowels of the giant, flying flesh-and-wood horse upon which you are travelling, where the horse-ship's captain lives in a dark hole and literally has a sextant for a head and a hammer for an arm. Where a beefy animal handler (actually, living rock handler) wears oven mitts, has a colander for a helmet, is armed with kitchen spatulas and yet still manages to look tough. And that's leaving out the weirdest things, the ones I don't even know how to describe.

When it comes to the plot, the best summary I can come up with is that once-peaceful paper farmer O'Sirus is given a mysterious quest by ... someone, to do ... something, for ... some reason. That's seriously about as clear as it gets, but that doesn't matter. It's the charm of setting out on an adventure and meeting a huge range of funny, friendly, cute or hostile characters that makes this game fun. You won't ever forget the people you meet on this journey, all distinct and memorable, from pocket sized Pokémon-types to room-filling hulks.

So it's high on intrigue factor. You will not have seen characters like this before unless you've smoked a lot of things you shouldn't, or you've played a lot of Zeno Clash. However, it's all too often that adventure games, especially those retro projects made with Adventure Game Studio (AGS), can't live up to the quality of their ideas with their production quality.

But Knobbly Crook's writer, artist, designer and voice actor, Ubisoft's Ethan Petty, doesn't do things half-a s s e d. (Well, other than the huge horse's a s s in the game, which he built with enough spare room to fit a bar into.) This is the kind of game you get from someone who's worked on Assassin's Creed, Watch_Dogs and Rainbow Six, now working on their passion project. That experience pays off in this little indie title that hits big with brilliant design on several counts.

Visually, we have the best-looking game I have ever seen made with AGS, with incredibly intricate mouse-drawn HD graphics that are part Mayan sculpture, part steampunk and part science textbook. You'll want to spend ages exploring every inch of each screen, not just to hunt for interactive objects as is the old-school adventure way, but to hunt for meaning in the assorted symbolism and just to appreciate the sinister beauty of it all. With the animation, we have nice multi-layered animated characters and occasional brief, endearingly weird close-up cutscenes at key points. The only things I felt were lacking were a couple more cutscenes showing the consequences of the player's actions as we were promised earlier in the chapter, possibly with a cowering captain in tow, but I'm sure that would have been lot of work for a joke lasting a few seconds.

With the sound, we have the fully-voiced, or I should say, fully-growled, dialogue that's a demonic-sounding version of English matching the deranged and murderous characters perfectly, with an amusingly contrasting jolly folk guitar soundtrack by Pitx.

With the writing, we have this intriguing parallel world with a completely different way of life, physical laws, and morality and yet that echos our world in interesting little ways that amuse and confuse in equal measure, keeping us on our toes in a really engaging way.

The adventure gameplay itself is the one area where the game doesn't try to break any moulds. You get the quests, hunt the items, mix them up in your inventory, and bring them back to advance the story. It's a pity that such a forward-looking game still has separate Walk, Look, Use, Take and Talk actions that need to be switched between by mashing your right click button, when left click and right click should do for such simple puzzles. Also, at a couple of points in the game, it's necessary to complete an action that isn't quite logically connected to the current goals in order to progress. Of course, as Petty has stated, this is a nostalgia project, so these gripes are partly a design choice and are pretty much standard for retro adventure games. I just don't feel that they add anything entertaining. The fact that this and a couple of absent cutscenes are the only significant criticisms I can make says a lot about the quality of the finished product.

If you're a point-and-click adventure game fan who remembers not just the puzzle mechanics of the 90's golden age, but also their offbeat black humour, this is the game you've been waiting for.

Excelling in design in multiple areas, notably the visuals and original story, and completely free, a gamer of any persuasion would be crazy not to download The Knobbly Crook, to take in the unique style of it all and especially to see what happens when someone finally makes the kind of game that inspired them as a kid.

reviewText:
06/24/2015 Edit: Review updated slightly for v1.1!

Short Review
If you like The Secret of Monkey Island, this game is sure to please at a price that can't be beat!    Even if you've never played a point-and-click adventure game before, this can still be quiet interesting from a few different angles.  The art is beautiful, the puzzles are interesting, and the music is just plain groovy.  It's definitely worth a shot, especially considering the price (or lack there-of)!  Just be warned... it can get gross and it will get weird at times!  But such is the world of the Knobbly Crook!

Long Review
So... After watching this game develop from it's pre-alpha stage, arrive on Steam Greenlight, and find a place in the Steam library of games, I finally decided to play around with Gnarled Scar Manipulation's little tale of a simple Knobbcrookian paper farmer.  Man, this game is gorgeous.  However, I have some issues... and I don't mean with the Goblin Legal System.

I had a hard time figuring out how to get this game to run in a window.  It turns out that you need to run the extra EXE file in the game's directory, WinSetup.exe"
date: to get the game into a window
recommended: among other things you might want (such as disabling the Knobbcrookian speech or changing rendering engines).  Not a real big problem if you just want to play the game
hoursPlayed: of course... but for some folks who like to multi-task

Not sure what could be done about this

reviewText:
8.5 - Thank-you drugs! You make interesting games.

Episode 1 shows some serious promise for the remainder of the series. It's not your run of the mill point and click. Extremely unique and artfully done. This is the first game I have played that is this odd, and this interesting. Sometimes I honestly don't know what the ♥♥♥♥ is going on but it doesn't seem to matter.

Navigation takes some time to get used to. Just take some time to fully look around and you will quickly get the hang of it. Play for more than 10 minutes and you will start to love this title.

It's FREE. So you should at least check this one out! Your objective in this episode is to get the crew to turn around the ship in order to get to Knobbly Crook. Each person and conversation you come across is an experience for sure. Love it or hate it... Extra points for different!

reviewText: I recently picked up this oldschool click-escape game, and enjoyed it greatly. Its simplistic mechanics do nothing to detract from the games overall aesthetic, and its challenging puzzles were obscure enough for me to spend quite some time mulling them over, though I didn't stoop low enough as to delve into the developer's included walkthrough. Perhaps the hardest part of the game, outside of the obvious conundrums, were the lack of instruction regarding the various interaction options that the player is allowed. But outside of that, the first installment of the Knobbly Crook is a glorious gem of a game with an art style reminiscient of surreal Lovecraftian Literature, which I enjoy greatly. And above all, it's free. What a time to be alive.

reviewText:
Product received for free

This was a nice 2 hours.  It took awhile and a little help from a YouTube Walkthru to get all the puzzles cpmpleted, but it was worth it.  The graphics are really well done, but the storyline and knowing what to do when can be a bit frustrating, but I guess that's what this type of adventure offers.

This game is not a big, fancy, beautifully rendered game like most are used to nowadays.  It's a fairly simple point-and-click type where you must find the answers to just how to get certain items to the correct person(s) and to do what's needed to complete this chapter of the game.

This is chapter #1.  The author promised chapter #2 this Summer.  For a free game, it's well worth it.

reviewText:
OverviewI love old-school P&C adventure games, but this one missed the mark for me.

What's wrong?    No coherent intro or context whatsoever. You don't even know who you are, what you're doing and are supposed to do, and what's going on. The story just starts with you in front of some weird machine and creature. You progress via trial and error.
No goals nor purpose. As the chapter proceeds, you get no closer to knowing what's going on, or what you're even supposed to do. All you encounter are weird creatures and things. There are no known objectives. You would think that as you advance, things would start becoming clearer... They don't.
Active areas are not indicated. I normally wouldn't have a problem with this, but given that you do not know what your goals are, and the world is a fantasy one with weird- and nonsensical-looking objects, how are you supposed to know what you can interact with and what you can't?! And randomly clicking to find out what's active or not is not my idea of productive gameplay.
Art style is tiring on the eyes. This wouldn't be so much of a problem if active objects were marked and you knew what you could click on and what you can't. Unfortunately, as I've mentioned above, since active objects are not indicated, you have to click around on anything and everything, and that means examining each scene carefully and in detail. The garishness of the artwork really gets to you after some time.
What's right?    It's free. So go ahead and try it for yourself if you are so inclined; there's nothing to lose here except time and bandwidth.
Unique art style. Outside of this game, I'd love the artwork, but not here, due to the reasons mentioned above under What's wrong?"
High production values. There's very decent voice acting
date: though characters all speak gibberish - apparently some in-game lingo. (There's text so you can decipher what they're saying.) The interface
voteText: etc all speak of high quality.\nIn a nutshell...If they fixed the intro/context and interactive objects issue
helpfulPercent: I would definitely give this another go."

reviewText: Okay so first off love the art style and idea its definetly unique and a lot of hardwork was put into the game. Though I wasnt able to finish the game I liked it but some of it was too hard to figure out or to understand what to do next so I used a guide. I couldnt finish the game not because I didnt want to but because my game was glitched because apparently you need to get grubs in the saw room and they werent there for me. I like the wacky story, background, ideas and characters and I wish I could have finished the game but I couldnt. But amazed that this is free because it is a really good game so far and it seems more like a game you would pay for rather than a free one. I would rate 8/10 just because I really like its potential to introduce more awesome ideas and because of the work put itno this.

Have you ever wondered what LSD was? Have you ever wanted to see a world not nearly as boring as the one you live in? Have you ever wanted to see a cool mask... I think. Well is THIS the game for YOU!

reviewText: Although this game confuses me and the visuals kinda disturb me, it was still fun while it lasted.

I had to open up a guide for some parts (I never was good with these kind of games) but I really like where this is going so far. The art style, animation, story elements, and 'voice acting' are reminscent of older games and overall outstanding! The voices are especially charming. :)
Challenging but not insanely difficult. Great visual design, and amusing.
Please make another chapter now! :)\n

At first I didn't care for the game. Figuring out what to do was difficult and it seemed silly. By mid-way through I realized O'sirus is insane, so that made figuring out what to do easier and made the game more fun. Now I can't wait for chapter 2! If you want a game with brain-teasing puzzles that make you think then this game isn't for you. If you want a game that's fun and will have you laughing often then download this now.
When i first opened this game i though hm this reminds me of BloodLust Software" then i saw the credits and Ethan Petty was on it! Great! Love this game
date: keep bringing new episodes! Greeting from a Time Slaughter fan :D"

reviewText: A brilliantly surreal old-school point and click adventure.

This is the first game of this genre I have played and I have to say I was thoroughly impressed. I have to recommend this to everybody, the dialogue is funny and entertaining, and the characters are very interesting as well. Best of all it's free so your not losing anything by checking it out.
Absolutely lovely and I cannot wait for chapter 2.

Awesome game. Love the art and the story/atmosphere.

There are some issues with gameplay but still.....loved it.

Thanks to the devs for this free gem.
I dont play point and clicks often so this one took me about two hours to beat, but it was well worth it. The game is great and im exited for chapter two.
The Knobbly Crook is an authentic point n' click adventure game featuring quirky characters, pleasant humour and interesting artwork.

It has a good sense of dark humor and a nice art. The music feels chilling. It won't require anything. I personally dislike the game for some reason, but i will recommend it because of the gameplay and the art it was done.
Love the atmosphere of the game. The voice acting is spot on too. The puzzles are nice and fairly straight forward and the story is interesting. Looking forward to more!

I had to open up a guide for some parts (I never was good with these kind of games) but I really like where this is going so far. The art style, animation, story elements, and 'voice acting' are reminscent of older games and overall outstanding! The voices are especially charming. :)
Please make another chapter now! :)\n

For an entirely free game to be released in multiple chapters this has very detailed drawings, fun interactions and hilarious commentary. The people that created this put a very large amount of time and effort into this game and by releasing it in seperate chapters are allowing themselves to be open to our reviews and thoughts.\n\n10/10 would sail horse again.

It is an interesting game, but the one thing that ruined it for me was that before the end of the game (there is score bar that indicates how much you've accomplished) I got stuck, I didn't know what to do and I was forced to look for a walkthrough. After watching the walkthrough video I realized that you have to use your items (in this case one particular item) in a pre-detirmined orded (the item had two purposes, if you use it for the second" purpose before you use it for the "first" it will disapear thus disabling you to move on)
date: and if you don't stick to that order
recommended: you can't finish the game and it was the second last thing I had to do to finish it. This kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off but I'm gonna go with a positive review because I enjoyed the three hours I've spent on it even though I didn't finish it.\nI'm gonna specify: Don't feed the Gong to the Gummerlung before you use it to kill the big green Gobold (or Bogold

reviewText: Very original. Well executed concept. I needed just a bit of help. Definitely 100% recommend.

I can't believe I didn't write a review of this game when I played it a handful of months ago. I loved it, it was free, and the title alone sold me on playing it. Well worth anyone's time to AT LEAST try it.\n\nIf you're a fan of adventure games, give it a go. It's completely free, and the lore is fascinating. Art style is singular and superb. Very interesting cast of characters.
